body.p: The concept of standard deviation is less intuitive as a measure of spread than the range or the IQR. The following activity is designed to help you develop a better intuition for the standard deviation.

At the end of a statistics course, the 27 students in the class were asked to rate the instructor on a number scale of 1 to 9 (1 being "very poor," and 9 being "best instructor I've ever had"). The following table provides three hypothetical rating data:
And here are the histograms of the data:
Now check your intuition by finding the actual standard deviations of the three rating distributions.

alternative.title: StatCrunch Instructions
alternative.p: To open the file (sdintuition.xls) in StatCrunch you must first right-click here and choose "Save Target As" to download the file to your computer. Next click here to open StatCrunch in a separate window and login using your username and password.

ul.li: Click on the link "Open StatCrunch" at the top of the My StatCrunch page.
To open the data set, click on the Data button in the top row and select Load → From file → on my computer.
Under File, press the Browse button and select the data set you downloaded.
Scroll to the bottom of the page and click on "Load File."

alternative.p: To ask StatCrunch for the descriptive statistics of the three distributions:

ul.li: In the Summary Stats window select the columns: Class I, Class II and Class III

li.p: To open Minitab with the data in the worksheet, right-click here and choose "Save Target As" to download the file to your computer. Then find the downloaded file and double-click it to open it in Minitab. Note: you will likely see a dialog box appear that says "A copy of the content of this file will be added to the current project"—just click OK.

ul.li:
To ask Minitab for the descriptive statistics of the three distributions:
Choose: Stat → Basic Statistics → Display Descriptive Statistics.
Under "Variables" enter the names of the three columns of data (or simply highlight them in the left panel and click "select").
Click OK.

To open Excel with the data in the worksheet, right-click here and choose "Save Target As" to download the file to your computer. Then find the downloaded file and double-click it to open it in Excel.

Use Excel to calculate the standard deviation of the three distributions:
Click a cell outside of the three columns of data, and type =stdev(A2:A28). That is the standard deviation for the first distribution.
Repeat for the other two distributions, adjusting the data range accordingly.

Then find the downloaded file and send it to your calculator. For instructions on how to connect your calculator to your computer and transfer a file, click here.
On the TI calculator, the dataset is displayed in lists L1-L3:
Now use the TI calculator to calculate the numerical measures of a distribution:
Note: you’ll have to repeat these steps for Ratings Class I (stored in L1), Ratings Class II (stored in L2), and Ratings Class III (stored in L3).

ul.li: Choose STAT/CALC/1:1-Var Stats. Specify which list the data are in; since the age data are in L1, you would enter 2ND/1 to choose L1. If you don't specify any particular list, the default list is L1.
The calculator will display the usual sample statistics and population parameters. We’re interested in Sx—sample standard deviation. Record the sample standard deviation (Sx) for each class.
